greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest multiple of n with digit sum = 6, or 0 if no such number exists, e.g. a(9k)= 0.
comment: In addition to those divisible by 9, all numbers n divisible by 239, 271 or 803 have a(n)=0. - _Robert Israel_, Sep 04 2019
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..2500
maple: evalb(S3 intersect map(t -> -t mod n, S3) = {});
Agenda:= remove(t -> (t mod 9=0 or t mod 239=0 or t mod 271=0 or t mod 803=0, {$1..N}):
found,Agenda:= selectremove(t -> x mod t = 0, Agenda);
if Agenda <> {} then printf("Values not found for %a\n",Agenda) fi;
mathematica: Array[If[AnyTrue[Mod[#, {9, 239, 271, 803}], # == 0 &], 0, Block[{k = 1}, While[Total@ IntegerDigits[k #] != 6, k++]; k #]] &, 59] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 04 2019 *)
results.author: _Amarnath Murthy_, Apr 01 2002
